A career officer in the Royal Tank Regiment (RTR) until 2010, he also served as an instructor and operations staff officer and then on the Challenger 2 (he was awarded the MBE for his efforts), the Multi Role Armoured Vehicle and the convoluted Future Rapid Effect System (FRES) programmes. Description: DORA is a disarmingly cute name for a major piece of legislation formally called the Digital Operational Resilience Act, which goes into effect in the EU in January 2025. DORA's primary objectives are to make financial systems more resilient against cyber threats and information communication technology (ICT) disruptions and, despite being EU legislation, is far-reaching in its impact across FS/Tech globally. It has been referred to as the GDPR of the financial sector due to stronger requirements and stricter enforcement. The ultimate responsibility for non-compliance with DORA is placed firmly on the financial institutions and their executives, with significant penalties for not achieving the required levels of comprehensive documentary evidence relating to compliance. For the March LNETM we‚Äôve teamed up with OwnData and Orrick to get to grips with what DORA truly means for an enterprise, how to get to grips with the challenges it brings and how to streamline compliance across the enterprise, particularly for data and cloud. We have brought together several industry-leading DORA experts for our discussion, including: This panel will be moderated by Matthew O‚ÄôNeill host of the ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Break the Bank‚Äù podcast, who will also provide the positioning talk. In addition, there will be flash talks from Own (formerly Own Backup), Mesh.ai and Cutover Software. Sincere thanks to London Stock Exchange Group for hosting the LNETM and to all our annual sponsors for 2024.
Title: The DORA Explorer
Subtitle: Get to grips with what DORA truly means for an enterprise, with the challenges it brings for  compliance and resilience in security & cloud

This ongoing era of technological advancement involves the seamless integration of digital, physical, and biological systems. As advanced robotics, artificial intelligence, genetic engineering, quantum computing, and other emerging technologies advance, how can academia and industry prepare for the new age? 4IR is not just a wave of innovation, but a strategic imperative for your business. It presents a multi-pronged approach to transform your business strategy, which could potentially: Businesses that can strategically leverage 4IR technologies are not only futureproofing their logn term goals but also positioning themselves to thrive in the evolving global business landscape and gain the important competitive edge. Description: Due to popular demand this event will now be taking place in the Lecture Theatre. A lot has happened in the copyright field recently. In the EU, Member States have now transposed the DSM Directive 2019/790 into their own laws (often in some substantially different ways) and related litigation has begun, already generating referrals to the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU). In parallel to that, there has been a steady flow of new EU legislation, including regulations - like the Digital Services Act and the AI Act - which are formally without prejudice to copyright rules, and yet will clearly define their meaning and scope of application going forward. In the UK, copyright case law does not (yet) appear to show an appetite for a divergence from the EU and CJEU approaches, with the latter's decisions remaining "good" even in a post-Brexit landscape. This talk will review the key copyright developments occurred over the past few months in the EU and UK, and identify emerging trends and open questions. A Visiting Professor at the Centre for Commercial Law Studies from 2024, Eleonora Rosati is Full Professor of Intellectual Property Law at Stockholm University and Of Counsel at Bird & Bird. She holds guest/visiting positions at several other institutions too, including Universidade Cat√≥lica Portuguesa, CEIPI-Universit√© de Strasbourg, Trinity College Dublin, EDHEC Business School, Glion Institute of Higher Education, and Centre for Intellectual Property and Information Law, University of Cambridge. Eleonora is Editor of the Journal of Intellectual Property Law & Practice (Oxford University Press), long-standing contributor to The IPKat, and Co-Founder of Fashion Law London. The author of several scholarly articles and books on IP issues, Eleonora regularly prepares technical briefings and expert opinions and delivers talks at the request of inter alia international organizations and EU institutions and agencies, as well as national governments and professional bodies and organizations. She has received multiple accolades and prizes for her work in the IP field, including: Managing Intellectual Property‚Äôs '50 Most Influential People in IP' globally (2018); World Intellectual Property Review‚Äôs 'Influential Women in IP' (2020); Adepi Award 2022 for contribution to shaping the interpretation of IP law in Europe (2022). The talk will be introduced and moderated by Professor Noam Shemtov, Chair in Intellectual Property and Technology Law and Director of the Queen Mary Intellectual Property Research Institute (QMIPRI), CCLS, Queen Mary University of London.
Organizer: The Centre for Commercial Law Studies, QMUL
Title: Recent and Emerging Trends in EU and UK Copyright
Subtitle: with Eleonora Rosati

Description: Synthesis of the human Mind ‚ÄúPhase deep into the Night to break high into the Light‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe MIND is a product of its KNOWING, not its THOUGHTS nor its THINKING, for they are easy to be influenced by the external world, but the Mind which is internal, is NOT them‚Äù. Our internal world drives our external world. Our ability to use our mind determines how well we can control our external realities. What you may not know is that our Minds have an identity. Creating an Identity of mind allows us to direct our external world intentionally. The language we use to run our lives is one dimensional, which creates needless limitations. Our minds work best in a multidimensional language. Learning how to access your minds resources correctly will enable you to create a life beyond who we desire to be. Our vocabulary, are words we use internally to motivate change, but instead of encouraging us, the imperfections in our speech and articulation restrict access to our minds. There is no synchronicity between the one-dimensional language in our speech and the 4 th dimension of the mind. If you‚Äôre not using the correct language of the mind, the mind disengages where we become confused. We don‚Äôt have the language to describe the life that we want in a way that the mind accepts, understands, and can utilise. Mind ReMapping is a language illuminating an internal identity, so that we no longer need to be afraid of the dark, neither do we need to be afraid of our minds and what the future holds for us. Meta Tech Organica ‚Äì Excited about Dimensions of LIVING D0 ‚Äì Orientation ‚Äì Who you are & who you are NOT. D1 ‚Äì Point of Focus ‚Äì What Where When Why & How to SEE. D2 ‚Äì Objectification ‚Äì Finding Imagination. D3 ‚Äì Understanding ‚Äì 4 Dimensions of Quadrilateral Thinking D4 ‚Äì TIME ‚Äì Mind ReMapping.(Cognitive Positioning System) Thank you for your patience. Mind ReMapping N.B. ALL EVENTS ARE ONLINE
Title: Mind ReMapping - LOST WITHOUT AN IDENTITY  - ONLINE -  Cambridge
Subtitle: The MIND ReMapping  Philosophy: "Be so Creatively removed from reality, that the Mind has no choice, but to come out of hiding‚Ä¶."

Description: This update on knowledge and skills will be invaluable to all lawyers representing children in the youth court and the Crown Court. The Bar Standards Board (BSB) requires barristers representing children to self-identify that they have the specialist skills, knowledge and attributes necessary to work effectively with vulnerable children and young people. The Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA) requires solicitors representing children in the criminal courts to undertake regular learning and development so their skills and knowledge remain up to date. All solicitors need to make an annual declaration to the SRA that they have done this. This training will ensure you meet your continuing competencies - the SRA | Good practice guide for youth court solicitors | Solicitors Regulation Authority states ‚ÄúA good youth court solicitor will maintain their competence by keeping their knowledge and skills up to date and applying them effectively in these areas: Knowledge and skills, Awareness of background and needs, Communication and Engagement.‚Äú The training will address these by providing: The training will be delivered in-person by leading expert youth justice lawyers including the founders of Just for Kids Law ‚Äì Aika Stephenson and Shauneen Lambe. The Ministry of Justice is funding this training as part of its commitment to encourage greater uptake of youth specific training for legal practitioners working with children. This kind of training, combined with increases in remuneration for youth court work, recognise the complexity and seriousness of working with child clients and the need for experienced legal practitioners who can provide high quality legal advice.
Title: FREE - Youth Justice Training for Lawyers in London
Subtitle: Update your Youth Justice knowledge and skills with expert lawyers Aika Stephenson and Shauneen Lambe, founders of Just for Kids Law.

Description: You‚Äôre looking for a fun way to see the sights as well as the lesser known spots. You love exploring and learning about the place, but big tour groups aren‚Äôt your thing. Have fun seeing Cambridge in a totally different way Solve satisfying clues and follow beautiful maps sent to your phones. Spot things other people take for granted! You‚Äôll learn interesting facts and stories. Find out more Because it‚Äôs all on your phones, it‚Äôs super flexible and there‚Äôs nothing to print. You'll have a laugh solving the clues and following the maps. Along the way you‚Äôll learn a few interesting facts and stories to keep you entertained. Something in a shop window catch your eye? No problem. Take it at your own pace. By the end of it all, you‚Äôll have a great overview of Cambridge and what you‚Äôd like to explore next. Check availability You don‚Äôt need to download or print anything and it doesn‚Äôt need any permissions. Plus, you get to start when you want. Bess sends you a series of treasure maps, leading you around the city. Bess sends you a series of clues and you have to search the city for answers. Along the way, Bess will tell you a few interesting facts and stories about the things you‚Äôre spotting!‚Äù Captain Bess will invite you and your friends to join the hunt! King's College Chapel the iconic gothic chapel and oldest surviving building within the College. Senate House where graduation has been held for the past 300 years. Great St Mary's Church this beautiful church dates back to 1205 and from the top of it's tower offers fantastic panormic views. Market Square stalls have been trading at this historic market square since the middle ages! The Corpus Clock a mesmerising and intriguing sculpture of a grasshopper eating away at time. Trinity, Catharine's and Queens College just three of the many prestigious colleges of the University of Cambridge you'll discover on this tour. Mathematical Bridge one of the most recognisable and interesting structures on the Cam, this timber footbridge has a rich history. The Backs a peaceful and picturesque stretch where several of the colleges back on to the River Cam. The Round Church At 900 years old, this church predates Newton and Darwin, the Colleges and the University! Check availability If it's patchy rain, you can stop somewhere on the route: the game‚Äôs flexible. If it's really bad on one day, you can either switch which day you play, or even start one day and finish the next. If it's a total wash-out and you can't get round, we‚Äôll give your money back, even if you've started the game. Don‚Äôt worry, if you get stuck you can ask for a hint and Bess will get you on your way! We make sure no-one ever gets completely stuck. It‚Äôs 2¬Ω miles walking but you can take as many breaks as you like. We‚Äôre so confident you‚Äôll have fun, we promise to give your money back if you don‚Äôt! All we ask is for a quick phone call to understand why.
Title: Treasure Hunt Cambridge - Colleges and Courtyards - 2-2¬Ω hours
Subtitle: Solve satisfying clues and follow beautiful maps sent to your phones. Spot things other people take for granted!

Description: Nowadays, some products and features are indeed ‚Äújust OpenAI wrappers‚Äù. But, to build compelling products that take advantage of GenAi models, there is still a lot of work, thought, and deliberation needed. What techniques and patterns do we need to learn to effectively unlock the potential of this revolution? We will go over patterns and techniques for building LLM-enabled applications and tools. We‚Äôll explore the current ecosystem and what fits where, as well as how we can take advantage of open-source libraries and models. We encounter ‚ÄúOpenAI wrappers‚Äù within various products and features, but building compelling products that harness GenAi models demands substantial effort. We must be intentional about employing techniques and patterns to optimise the potential of the AI-Native revolution. This session aims to provide valuable insights and practical advice for leaders and managers seeking to navigate the evolving landscape of cloud technologies and AI integration. Key discussion points include: By the end of this session, participants will be equipped with a nuanced understanding of the historical context, current challenges, and strategic considerations surrounding cloud technologies and AI. The goal is to empower leaders to navigate this rapidly evolving landscape, unlocking the full potential of AI-Native solutions for their organizations. The Speaker: S√©rgio Ramos, Head of Engineering at YLD. Sergio is responsible for pushing the business in the right technical direction and has done so, as a full-stack engineer, almost since YLD‚Äôs humble beginnings. When he is not solving complex technical problems for our clients, he provides consulting as well as internal and external training. Sponsored by: YLD are a software engineering and design consultancy, that helps you succeed by moving your team from a culture of delivery to a culture of learning. Hosted by: CTO Craft is a learning and mentoring community for senior technology leaders, with a community of thousands of leaders, annual conferences, mentoring groups and one-to-one coaching, as well as exclusive courses and workshops through the Campus platform. Community membership is free, so if you're leading technology teams, you should get involved. Only open to CTOs and senior technology leaders. If you‚Äôre not sure if that‚Äôs you - please drop us a line. CTO Craft reserves the right to cancel tickets for ineligible ticket holders.
Title: CTO Craft Bytes: Beyond just an OpenAI wrapper
Subtitle: At this in-person event, we'll be exploring what we need to learn to effectively unlock the potential of the GenAI revolution.

Description: Tackling climate change is everyone‚Äôs business. At Wandsworth Council we know we have a key role to play but it is only together, with you, our partners, communities, local businesses, and experts in the field that we can address this ‚Äì the greatest challenge of our time.¬†¬† We know action is underway through a range of activity across the borough ‚Äì but we also know we need to do more ‚Äì and faster. As a Council we have recently commissioned research into the collective action that is needed for our borough to be net zero by 2043. If we work together and share our learning we have great potential to harness the energy and expertise of the many talents that want to make a difference.¬† In that spirit we have arranged a Net Zero Summit so that we can share the findings of the research, hear from industry experts, stakeholders and funders on the action they have taken and the support they can provide.¬†¬† ¬†Our aim is to build a clearer picture on the action we can each take to move us towards this target. As part of the day we will be delivering ‚ÄúTogether on Climate Knowledge‚Äù training¬† - an opportunity to earn an accreditation as well as build each of our individual knowledge of the issue at hand and the impact we can each make.¬†¬†
Title: Wandsworth Together on Climate Change - Net Zero Summit
Subtitle: An opportunity to share local research findings, hear from industry experts, stakeholders and funders on action taken and support provided.

Description: This course will teach you how to weave three dimensional shapes using different sized willow to create decorations for your garden. You will learn how to make a sphere and a dragonfly using basic basketry techniques such as the random weave. You will also have the opportunity to make a two dimensional star. Crafts using your hands can be a therapeutic and an enjoyable experience. Make your very own handmade items to give as gifts or keep for your own garden. This course is suitable for all levels including beginners. All materials and tools provided. Costs: ¬£45 Times: 18:00 - 21:00 Dates: Tuesday 12 Mar Room: White Room Maximum: 8 Sarah Gardner trained as textile designer, this sparked her interest in constructed textiles and led to her practicing basketry for the past 7 Years. She is interested in growing and foraging natural materials for making but also has a make-do-and-mend approach and is always on the look-out for man-made materials that can be adapted or useful in basket-making. This requires a lot of testing to work out the qualities of the materials and their suitability for different weaving techniques. As an advocate for the crafts Sarah also helps run a small leather accessories company and teaches and practices basketry in Brighton.
Title: Willow Garden Decorations with Sarah Gardner
Subtitle: Learn how to weave with willow to create decorations for your garden

Description: We look forward to welcoming you to our annual Institute for Lifecourse Development ‚Äì Equality, Diversity and Inclusion Research Conference, hosted by the Centre for Inequalities, ILD, University of Greenwich. Academic speakers from across the ILD will discuss a variety of different EDI topics. This year‚Äôs talks will cover methodological considerations, including co-design within educational contexts, participant recruitment in healthcare studies, inequities in scientific writing, and historical research into widening participation. A keynote speech will be given by Professor Anya Ahmed from Manchester Metropolitan University, whose research will reflect on the theoretical and practical implications of two studies, conducted almost 20 years apart, which focus on minoritized ethnic communities and their experiences of health and social care services. Through a temporal and positional lens, situating such experiences in broader structural contexts, Prof. Ahmed will consider how change and continuity intersect in health and wellbeing outcomes for minoritized ethnic populations, and how these are inextricably linked to enduring social inequalities. The event will end in a panel discussion and networking opportunity. 4.00 - 4.15pm Registration - refreshments available 4.15 - 4.30pm Welcome to the event Prof Sofia Stathi 4.30 - 4.45pm ‚ÄúDeveloping a questionnaire for a UK child abuse prevalence survey‚Äù Dr Julia Rudolph 4.45 - 5.00pm ‚ÄúCo-Designing an Inclusive Community of Practice for Transformative Participatory Educational Research to Restore Trust‚Äù Prof Jill Jameson 5.00 - 5.15pm ‚ÄúAddressing modern-coloniality and inequity in international social scientific research writing‚Äù Dr Fouad Bou Zeineddine 5.15 - 5.30pm ‚ÄúAchieving equality, diversity and inclusivity in research recruitment‚Äù Prof Lesley Dibley 5.30 - 5.45pm ‚ÄúWidening Participation in the early 1900s: New research on our heritage- the Woolwich Polytechnic Day Schools‚Äù Dr Mary Clare Martin 5.45 - 6.00pm ‚ÄúEDI considerations in research‚Äù Dr Sandhiran Patchay 6.00 - 6.15pm Break 6.15 - 6.45pm Keynote ‚ÄúChange and continuity: the intersection of health and social inequalities‚Äù Prof Anya Ahmed 6.45 - 7.15pm Panel discussion / Q&A forum 7.15 - 7.30pm Closing remarks Data protection statement: The information that we are collecting from you will be used by the University of Greenwich to administer this event. We will create a delegate list of attendees, and will keep a record of your attendance. We will also use the contact details provided to email you with further details about the event. The details you have provided will also be held by the university and used only to inform you about the Institute for Lifecourse Development - including future events which may be of interest and our ITE partnership newsletter. To remove your details from our record, please contact us at ILD@gre.ac.uk or unsubscribe in future emails.
Title: Equality Diversity and Inclusion Research Conference 2024
Subtitle: The Centre for Inequalities hosts this annual research conference to showcase the important research on EDI issues conducted within the ILD.

Description: Professor Hughes has lectured on Middle Eastern politics and military history both at home and abroad. His latest monograph on British counter-insurgency in Palestine in the 1930s entitled Britain's Pacification of Palestine: the British Army, the Colonial State, and the Arab Revolt, 1936-1939 (2019, paperback edition 2020) published with Cambridge University Press was a 'commended' finalist for the 2019 Society for Army Historical Research Templer Medal Prize, was long listed for the British Army Military Book of the Year 2020. Britain‚Äôs crushing of the 1936‚Äì1939 Arab revolt against Jewish immigration to and British rule in Mandate Palestine was at heart an administrative war by an Emergency State. Military search-and-sweep operations after 1936 played second fiddle to systemic (and systematic) politico-legal pacification of the whole country by undemocratic colonial government. The target was the people. Of the three variables determining victory or defeat in Palestine ‚Äì insurgent action, British counter-insurgency military operations, and the colonial Emergency State ‚Äì this Ealing HA talk argues that the last was the key to victory. The Arab revolt was a clash between disorganized insurgency versus well-organized colonial civil rule that drove forward pacification by collectively and legally punishing Palestinians. Powerful colonial legal-administrative structures won the battle, as will be discussed. Pacification of the population was more significant than the military suppression of rebellion. This started not in 1936, but in 1920 with the arrival of the first civil High Commissioner for Palestine and the establishment of collective punishment laws.
Title: Talk on ‚ÄòThe Arab Revolt in Palestine in the 1930s‚Äô
Subtitle: This talk focuses on British colonial counter-insurgency measures in Palestine in  the years 1936 to 1939

Description: Transitions towards software-defined vehicles, automation, shared mobility and circularity, will require radical departures from the status quo in the design of automotive enabled-mobility. Differentiation through software, purpose built vehicles, resource intelligence, ethics, and passenger-centric vehicles are amongst the key factors that will redefine the needs and requirements of future vehicles, with robotics and artificial intelligence being one of their crucial enablers from the initial stages of data-driven design to manufacturing, testing and deployment. This collaboration between Intelligent Mobility Design Centre and the Robotics Laboratory at the Royal College of Art and AESIN‚Äôs Research and Innovation SIG aims to bring together representatives from across the industry and academia to better understand how future mobility design stand to play a critical role in the future of automotive electronics and software. This event seeks to explore emerging areas of automotive-enabled mobility design over a 10-15 year time horizon. Our driving focus would be the future state of automotive electronics and software, which underpins the plausible scenarios for future mobility and associated industries. A selection of speakers will share insights from their understanding and experience to provide a context to the wider discussions, along with group discussions.
Title: Roadmapping the Future of Automotive-enabled Mobility Design
Subtitle: Roadmapping Research Challenges for the Future of Automotive-enabled Mobility Design

Description: Exploring sacred space. Come and walk a Labyrinth under the magnificent Dome of St Paul's. Experience Wren's sacred space created to inspire awe and wonder. Enjoy the tranquillity and stillness of the Nave and Transepts in the early evening. You are also welcome to join the daily service of Evensong beforehand at 5pm and conclude your experience with a short service of night prayer at 7.45pm. You will receive a short written explanation about labyrinths and suggestions for how to make the most of your experience. Staff will be available to help you and answer any questions. When you register you will be asked to choose which timed slot you would like to attend - this is the time that you will be able to walk the Labyrinth but you will be able to enter the Cathedral at 4.45pm for the 5pm Evensong, or at any time after 6.10pm, in order to enjoy the peace and quiet of the Cathedral in the evening. Anything else I need to know? We'll ask you to take your shoes off to walk the Labyrinth so you might want to wear your best socks! Your ticket will allow you into the Cathedral to walk the Labyrinth and explore the Nave and Transepts but the rest of the Cathedral including the Crypt will be closed. It doesn't allow you access to the Galleries or to an audio guide. During this evening there will be an opportunity to experience a Christian mindfulness taster session lasting 20 minutes. The session will run twice, once at 6.30pm and again at 7pm. The sessions will be led by Martin Zetter of Mindful WorkLife who helps busy people to use meditation and mindfulness to manage stress. Christian mindfulness is an awareness of God in the present moment. It has the benefit of growing our relationship with God‚Äôs love and deepening that sense of connection to other people and the whole of creation. It also brings the same benefits to our physical and mental well-being as secular mindfulness.
Organizer: Adult Learning at St Paul's Cathedral
Title: Labyrinth Evening
Subtitle: You are invited to explore the sacred space of St Paul's Cathedral by walking our Labyrinth under the Dome.

Description: At the Centre for Responsible Leadership we believe that social capital is a social good. Join us for ‚ÄúThe Power of Connection‚Äù, the second of our Leadership Generations event series in which Professor Celia Moore will talk to two leaders, Diane Morgan (Stepex, Emerge Education, Zinc VC, Trilogy) and Farhan Lalji (LTV Capital, Anthemis, Rokk3r Labs, Yahoo) about the transformative effect of social connection on leadership capability. The discussion will reveal non traditional approaches to nurturing social capital which can be adopted by anyone in a way that is genuine, fulfilling and ultimately impactful for individuals themselves and the communities which they serve. Whether you're a seasoned leader, an emerging leader, or simply passionate about making a difference, the Leadership Generations event series is your gateway to more responsible and innovative approaches to leadership. Subtitle: Celia Moore in conversation with Diane Morgan and Farhan Lalji on the role of social capital in effective leadership.

Description: Metternich and Bismarck were the two leading diplomats of the nineteenth century, both spending decades in power although both depended on dynastic support. Both used force to overthrow the existing European order after which they made the preservation of peace and the isolation of France their main priorities. Both were highly conservative monarchists although neither was truly reactionary. Their two systems were linked by their common view of Central Europe. On balance Metternich was probably the better statesman. Speaker: Alan Sked is Emeritus Professor of International History at the LSE, where he spent his entire academic career after taking his D. Phil at Oxford under the supervision of A. J. P. Taylor. He has published on European, British and American history and is a world authority on the Habsburg Monarchy. His books include ‚ÄòThe Decline and Fall of the Habsburg Empire, 1815-1918‚Äô, ‚ÄòMetternich and Austria. An Assessment‚Äô and ‚ÄòRadetzky. Imperial Victor and Military Genius‚Äô. Image credit: Otto Von Bismarck in 1894 wearing the uniform of the regiment of Cuirassier named after him (left) and Clemens Lothar Wenzel, Prince Metternich (right), Wikimedia
Title: Metternich and Bismarck Compared
Subtitle: A SSEES Study of Central Europe seminar with Professor Alan Sked

Description: Join us for the second event in the Wild Court Reading Series. For this event, our featured reader is poet, novelist, musician, Kings lecturer and winner of the 2022 T.S. Eliot Prize Anthony Joseph. Anthony will read from his forthcoming Precious and Impossible: New & Selected Poems published by Bloomsbury this autumn, and be in conversation with Luke Roberts Senior Lecturer in Modern Poetry at Kings College. Dr Anthony Joseph F.R.S.L. is an award winning Trinidad-born poet, novelist, academic and musician. His collection Sonnets for Albert won the T.S. Eliot Prize for Poetry 2022 and the OCM BOCAS Prize for Caribbean Poetry. He is the author of four previous poetry collections and three novels. His 2018 novel Kitch: A Fictional Biography of a Calypso Icon was shortlisted for the Republic of Consciousness Prize, the Royal Society of Literature‚Äôs Encore Award and the OCM Bocas Prize for Caribbean Fiction. His most recent fiction publication is the experimental novel The Frequency of Magic. In 2019, he was awarded a Jerwood Compton Poetry Fellowship. As a musician, he has released eight critically acclaimed albums, and in 2020 received a Paul Hamlyn Foundation Composers Award. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature and a Lecturer in Creative Writing at Kings College, London. Dr Luke Roberts is a poet and writer. He is the author of Home Radio (2021), Glacial Decoys (2021), and other works of poetry and prose. He is co-editor of So Much For Life: Selected Poems by Mark Hyatt (Nightboat, 2023), and editor of Mark Hyatt's novel Love, Leda (Peninsula, 2023). He is a Senior Lecturer in Modern Poetry at Kings College, London. Strand K2.29 Council Room is located on level 2 of King's Building. Exit the lift, and then turn right onto the main corridor and Council Room K2.29 is on the left hand side.‚Äã
Title: The Wild Court Reading Series: Anthony Joseph
Subtitle: For our second edition our featured reader is award winning poet, novelist, musician and lecturer Anthony Joseph

Description: Certificate: Course Completion Certificate Language: English Duration: 1 Day Credits: 8 Course Delivery: Classroom/ Virtual Live/ On-Site Course Overview: The Encarta Dictionary defines knowledge management as the organization of intellectual resources and information systems within a business environment. Sounds pretty simple, right? Take a moment, though, and think about all the information that each person has in their brain. That‚Äôs a lot of knowledge! The Knowledge Management workshop will give participants the tools that they will need to begin implementing knowledge management in your organization, no matter what the size of the company or the budget. Wherever there are humans working together for one goal, there is knowledge to be harvested, stored, and dispensed as needed. Target Audience: Anybody who is interested in learning Knowledge Management Skills Learning Objectives: After completing this course, Individuals will be able to demonstrate their understanding of:  Prerequisites: None Course Materials: Attendees will receive a course manual with presentation slides and reference materials. Description: There is already a startling statistic that only 14% of women are angel investors in Scotland (putting your own money into early stage companies in return for stock / shares) and only 2% equity goes to women led companies in the UK. With the latest FCA regulation on the 31 Jan increasing the minimum financial limits that define a High Net Worth, historically the main route into angel investing, we will talk about the alternative routes to bridge this gap with a focus on how we can spread the word to support more women to become angels. It is now possible to become an angel through online education and be located anywhere in the world! The Scottish Business Network through collaboration with Mint Ventures have assembled an extremely knowledgeable panel to help address this and not allow the new regulations detrimentally impact society: Rachel Curtis - Ignicio AI Rachel has spent 30 years in the Financial Services arena including at Santander and then as Chief Customer Officer for a challenger bank.  She still sits as a Non-Executive Director for a regional Building Society, holding the role of Consumer Duty Board Champion. In 2021 Rachel made the switch to lead a Fintech start-up that has a B2B software platform that uses conversational AI to help organisations to support their customers to complete detailed affordability assessments. Rachel recently graduated from the Morgan Stanley Inclusive Ventures Lab where she secured one of only 9 places across EMEA from over 4,000 applicants.
Title: Mint Ventures & SBN: How do we bridge the gap on Angel Investment?
Subtitle: Have you ever wondered how you can become involved in angel investing and give back to help shape the future of Scotland's economy ?

Description: What is Earth? What is a solar system? What is humanity? Who is Florian Yuriev? Why did he build a UFO building in Kyiv? Will we be able to use it for its intended purpose in the future? SAVA Creative Fellow Oleksiy Radynski‚Äôs Infinity According to Florian (2022, 70 minutes) deals with these questions, related to the legendary figure of Kyiv-based architect Florian Yuriev. This film also recounts why capitalism is a thing of the past, and what happens when you divide one by infinity. After having a world premiere at the International Film Festival Rotterdam, Infinity According to Florian has been screened at festivals including Docs Against Gravity, DocAviv, Krakow IFF, Sheffield Doc Fest, DOK Leipzig and others, and received the Kinokolo Best Ukrainian Documentary Award from the Union of Ukrainian Film Critics. Oleksiy Radynski is a filmmaker based in Kyiv. His films have been screened at the International Film Festival Rotterdam, the Oberhausen International Short Film Festival, DOK Leipzig, Kurzfilmtage Winterthur and other festivals, and received awards at Docudays UA, Molodist IFF, and the Kyiv International Short Film Festival. Selected Filmography: Infinity According to Florian (2022), Circulation (2020), Facade Colour: Blue (2019), The Film of Kyiv. Episode One (2017), Landslide (2016), People Who Came to Power (2015), Integration (2014), Incident at the Museum (2013). The research of Robin Schuldenfrei (Courtauld Institute of Art) focuses on the history and theory of modern architecture. She is interested in broad questions‚Äîtheoretical and practical‚Äîof how discourses and practices of design are shaped by a given period‚Äôs own cultural and theoretical critique of its media and objects. Her work interrogates the ways in which architecture and its objects relate to other products of society‚Äôs design: to works of art, to the production of images, to media, and to technology. She is the author of Objects in Exile: Modern Art and Design across Borders, 1930‚Äì1960 (2024). The Socialist Anthropocene in the Visual Arts (SAVA) is a visual arts led interdisciplinary research project that challenges the West-centric discourses of the Anthropocene by asserting the constitutive role of the environmental histories of Socialism in the formation of the new geological age. Led by Dr. Maja Fowkes at UCL Institute of Advanced Studies, the project was selected for a Consolidator Grant by the European Research Council (ERC) and is funded by UK Research and Innovation (UKRI). www.sava.earth Image: Oleksiy Radynski, Infinity According to Florian, 2022. Video still. Courtesy the artist.
Title: SAVA: Screening of Oleksiy Radynski‚Äôs Infinity According to Florian
Subtitle: A screening of SAVA Creative Fellow Oleksiy Radynski‚Äôs film Infinity According to Florian (2022) with responses from Robin Schuldenfrei.

Description: We are running out of time. 2023 was one of the most volatile climate years in history, and the mealy outcomes of COP28 make it clear that incremental politics aren't going to save us. Is there any hope of achieving the systemic changes needed to address climate change before it's too late? In SAVING OURSELVES: From Climate Shocks to Climate Action author Professor Dana R. Fisher charts a realistic path forward for climate action--but only by mobilizing people power to push for the necessary changes. Join Dana Fisher (Director of the Center for Environment, Community, & Equity at American University) as she discusses her three-point agenda for transformative climate action: Build Community, Capitalize on Moral Shocks, and Cultivate Resilience. Host/chair: Dr Ben Abrams, Deputy Director, UCL Sociology Network / Lecturer in Sociology, Department of Education, Practice and Society, IOE, UCL
Title: SAVING OURSELVES: From Climate Shocks to Climate Action
Subtitle: Is there any hope of achieving the systemic changes we need to address climate change before it's too late?

Description: Histories of the post-Reformation Church of (and in) England are, as is well known, often incompatible with each other. Much of the relevant scholarly output of recent times has been taken up with trying to resolve existing contradictory interpretations of what, exactly, happened at and after the Reformation. The same ur-texts (Cranmer, Jewel, Andrewes et al.) are frequently cited as authorities by those who see the English Church in completely different ways. Likewise, political narratives that are technically about the same topic often focus on quite different things. It has never been easy to say exactly what we mean by terms such as 'puritanism', 'Calvinism', 'Laudianism', and so on. Consensus and agreement are, frankly, not expected or likely any time soon. But there have been similar divergences in the narratives compiled by those in the past who wanted to narrate overtly 'Catholic' accounts of the Long Reformation. Putting these alongside the better known 'Anglican' disagreements on such matters tells one something about both of them. Not least, it allows for a discussion of what we might take to be the 'Catholic' tradition in the Church of England. All are welcome, but those wishing to attend should book a free ticket or email archives@churchofengland.org no later than Monday 11 March. Please note that tickets must be booked individually for security purposes.
Title: Institute of Historical Research Seminar
Subtitle: Michael Questier (Durham University): Rome and the Anglicans ‚Äì and their Histories of the Reformation

Description: The Design Council in partnership with Impact on Urban Health invites you to discover the latest findings from their health and wellbeing innovation programme, Employee Health Innovation Fund. Join industry leaders and policymakers to hear directly from participating employers about how they used design-led approaches to better understand and respond to the health and wellbeing needs of their organisations. This event will feature practical stories, a panel Q&A, and a look to the future of health at work and how this contributes to greater health equity for all workers. About the Employee Health Innovation Fund The Employee Health Innovation Fund started from an understanding that improving access to meaningful, inclusive and healthy working environments is an effective way of improving the health of employees across a range of sectors. Employers can make a real difference in their employee‚Äôs lives by creating healthier working conditions and an open culture that supports employees to build and maintain better health. The fund supported employers based in Lambeth & Southwark to create and test evidence-based or evidence-creating interventions to improve the health and wellbeing of employees living on lower incomes living with, or at risk of developing one or more long-term health conditions. What to expect We look forward to seeing you there.

Description: The prestigious London Book Fair will return to the Olympia London in March 2024. This annual event has been held for over 40 years and has been the global marketplace for rights negotiation and distribution across film and digital channels. The theme for this year‚Äôs fair revolves around the future of content across an even more rapidly transforming media landscape. There will be over 100 seminars expected to be held, along with awards given to exceptional authors whose works have made a powerful impact on the reading public during the last few years. The fair will also be a place for learning, networking, and discussion on key industry challenges such as sustainability and innovation. The upcoming LBF will focus on the rapid changes to the wider content landscape, such as the impact of new narratives, the arrival of A.I. technologies, the call for more representation, and more. The previous LBF was already bustling with professionals from the entire publishing industry ‚Äì publishers, copyright pros, commissioners, and global licensers ‚Äì networking, all the while hundreds of authors and other creators explored and exchanged ideas. 2024 aims to be even livelier, more engaging, more creative, and more productive for pioneering the future of creative content.
Title: ReadersMagnet Join the London Book Fair 2024
Subtitle: LBF 2024 looks to the future of creative content.

Description: The Bulgarian Cultural Institute London is pleased to invite you to an event with the translator Angela Rodel, winner, together with the great Bulgarian writer Georgi Gospodinov, of the prestigious international Booker prize. Angela Rodel will present the first English translation of the Bulgarian classic from the 20th century ‚Äì Vera Mutafchieva‚Äôs The Case of Cem.  Angela Rodel will be in conversation with writer Hannah Hutchings-Georgiou. It‚Äôs 1481, and as seen from the centers of power in Rome and Venice, the cultures of Europe are under threat from the expansion of the Ottoman Empire. When the exalted Sultan Mehmed the Conqueror dies, his eldest son, Bayezid, takes the throne. However, discontented factions within the Ottoman army urge Mehmed‚Äôs second son, Cem, a well-educated and experienced warrior, to oppose his brother‚Äôs ascension, igniting a ruthless power struggle and forcing Cem into long years of exile, a pawn for European rulers who are desperate to preserve the order they have imposed on the continent over the course of centuries. The Case of Cem, Vera Mutafchieva‚Äôs celebrated novel of court intrigue, maintains lasting resonance for being a personal exploration of emigration and loss set in the historical era during which the politics of the East and West were sketched out with utter clarity. These early lines of demarcation, as voiced through Christian and Muslim emissaries, greedy leaders, unflinching soldiers, and lyrical poets, have indelibly influenced the world as we know it today. Vera Mutafchieva (1929-2009) is one of the most influential Bulgarian writers of the 20th century and undisputedly the most prominent female novelist in the Bulgarian canon. A historian of the Ottoman Empire by training, Mutafchieva is known for her intricate historical novels that offer nuanced insight into the complex layers of Balkan history, with its Slavic, Ottoman, and Byzantine Greek threads. After the success of The Cem Affair in 1967, Mutafchieva shifted her energy primarily toward literary endeavors, writing 35 books that feature figures from Balkan history, ranging from Bulgarian tsars to the Byzantine princess Anna Komina. Mutafchieva‚Äôs works have been translated into more than a dozen languages and have enjoyed particular popularity in neighboring Balkan countries.Angela Rodel is a literary translator who holds degrees from Yale and UCLA. Nine Bulgarian novels in her translation have been published in the US and UK, and shorter works have appeared in McSweeney‚Äôs, Two Lines, Ploughshares, Words Without Borders, and elsewhere. She has received NEA and PEN translation grants. Her translation of Georgi Gospodinov‚Äôs Physics of Sorrow won the 2016 AATSEEL Prize for Literary Translation, while her translation of his novel Time Shelter was featured on The New Yorker‚Äôs list of Best Books of 2022 and won the 2023 International Booker Prize. Since 2015 she has served as executive director of the Bulgarian-American Fulbright Commission. Hannah Hutchings-Georgiou is a writer and the founding editor-in-chief of Lucy Writers. She edits all Arts sections (Art & Design, Books, Dance, and Creative Writing especially). She completed her BA in English Literature at Lucy Cavendish College, Cambridge, and has an MA in Eighteenth-Century Studies from King‚Äôs College, London. She is currently writing up her PhD in English Literature at UCL and teaches undergraduate students in the department. She regularly writes for online magazines and platforms such as The London Magazine, The Arts Desk, The White Review, Burlington Contemporary, Plinth UK, The Asymptote Journal, Club des Femmes, Women: A Cultural Review and many others. Hannah has co-run a creative writing workshop for women for several years, as well as a feminist reading group. She writes about contemporary art & culture, in particular visual art, literature and dance.https://lucywritersplatform.com/author/hannah/
Title: English translation of Vera Mutafchieva‚Äôs "The Case of Cem" by Angela Rodel
Subtitle: The Case of Cem by Vera Mutafchieva: A Conversation between translator Angela Rodel and Hannah Hutchings-Georgiu

Description: Shakti writes: "I will present a long-term field study investigating the effects of the demographic and social structure of communities on cooperative behaviour. The study has been conducted with the matrilocal Khasi and the patrilocal Pahari Korwa peoples in India over the past decade. Our multilevel and longitudinal study design allows us to tease apart the effects of different facets of community structure on cooperation. "We have measured cooperation in a variety of different ways including surveys, experiments and a novel community well building project, which allows us to understand how people‚Äôs behaviour differs across different contexts. My talk will be accompanied by an exhibition exploring the story and science of the community well building project via videos of the project as it unfolded. I hope to highlight the ways in which this project contributes to a growing movement for open, transparent, inclusive and engaged research." Shakti Lamba is an anthropologist and ecologist studying the evolution of cooperation and culture in humans. She is speaking LIVE in the Daryll Forde, 2nd Floor of the UCL Anthropology Dept, you can just turn up at UCL (NB you need to use the Archaeology Institute entrance).  You can also join us on ZOOM (ID 384 186 2174 passcode Wawilak) https://us02web.zoom.us/j/3841862174 ( Passcode: Wawilak) Accompanying her talk, Shakti will show a video exhibition of the Building Well project just beforehand (5:45-6:30pm in Room 129, classroom on 1st Floor beneath the Daryll Forde).
Title: Building well together: a study of human cooperation
Subtitle: Evolutionary anthropologist Shakti Lamba talks on her work in India on how humans organise  commons systems on a volunteer basis

Description: Full day of CPD for teachers at London state primary schools and SEND settings. Explore a range of creative teaching approaches proven to elevate higher-order thinking, reading, writing, and spoken language across primary years. Teachers will be supported to develop extended units inspired by high-quality texts, fostering literacy proficiency and creative thinking across the curriculum. This Masterclass will be delivered by an expert advisory teacher from CLPE in partnership with award-winning children‚Äôs author S.F. Said and will support teachers and leaders to plan for increased engagement and attainment in reading across the primary years. We will explore the breadth of research that connects reading for pleasure with reading attainment, and the ways in which the act of reading expands understanding of language, vocabulary and knowledge of the world. We will consider the role of all adults in school as readers, creating a culture in which children can be influenced to read widely and for pleasure, as well as the practices that enable teacher and peer book recommendations to take place and which build reading habits and reader identity. We will demonstrate creative teaching approaches that give all children access to high quality texts, and that are designed to target specific reading skills and increase children‚Äôs motivation to read with a greater depth of understanding, leading to increased engagement and attainment across your school. We will reflect on the importance of providing a range and breadth of carefully chosen quality children‚Äôs literature in developing engaged and motivated readers across the school. We will also look at ways in which schools make this stock accessible; developing children‚Äôs self-selection and independence in reading and fostering a love of reading across the school community. Key areas of focus Please note: Places will be limited to two participants per school. This is an all day event and refreshments and lunch catering will be provided. Who can take part?  Primary Arts is open to all state primary mainstream and special schools in London. The programme is designed to include children in all primary year groups from Reception to Year 6.  Your school must be in a London borough to be eligible for the programme.  Schools and individuals can take part in more than one strand of the programme (but only one touring booking can be made per school). Description: Why would you want to do this Insight Session? About the speaker Maisie Clater, talent coordinator of Studio Lambert. Studio Lambert The name Studio Lambert has a history that spans more than half a century. Studio Lambert is a fast-growing independent television production company based in London, Manchester, Glasgow and Los Angeles. It is part of All3Media, the global production group.  Stephen Lambert, creator of many well-known global formats including Wife Swap, Secret Millionaire and Faking It, launched the company in 2008. It quickly grew a reputation on both sides of the Atlantic for making innovative and popular unscripted shows. Description: Join us to see our latest show, participate in an informal drop-in workshop, and meet with the Learning team. This event is a great opportunity to find out more about what we do, see examples of recent projects and discuss how we can support visual arts provision at your school, but also to relax, chat and make.  Food and wine provided. More details of the drop-in workshop will be announced nearer to the event. All materials will be provided.  Mark of Cane explores the impact of sugar on the African-Caribbean Diaspora, confronting the haunting legacies of the Industrial Revolution and the Transatlantic Slave trade. Bow Arts is delighted to present a solo exhibition by Kat Anderson, winner of the inaugural East London Art Prize. Anderson will premiere ‚ÄòLas, Fiya‚Äô (‚ÄòLast, Fire‚Äô), a fictional short film which uses the genre of Horror to explore the subjects of ancestral trauma, dispossession and the power in the return/retrieval. The exhibition is an immersive, audio-visual experience, centred around the new single-channel, fictional short film, and accompanied by new paperworks. Shot largely on an existing sugarcane farm in Jamaica, the film weaves historical methods of harvesting sugarcane and sugar production with the cinematic concept of the ‚ÄòOrigin Story‚Äô. The accompanying series of paperworks have been hand-made from the extracted by-products of sugarcane, produced as part of Anderson‚Äôs residency at UCL East, where a special cane crusher and boiler furnace will be used to extract materials for the paper-making process. In line with the larger project ‚ÄòEpisodes of Horror‚Äô, Mark of Cane questions the emancipatory potential of creativity, reclamation and listening to history. Sugarcane becomes a vessel, both narratively and materially, for an imaginative and impactful examination of colonial histories. The work invites conversations around the forced and coerced movements of Black African-Caribbean people, from slavery through to the Windrush generation and its subsequent scandal. Kat Anderson was the winner of the inaugural East London Art Prize in 2023. The winner of the prize presents the winner‚Äôs solo exhibition the following year. More on the East London Art Prize. Anderson‚Äôs film has been supported by funds from Arts Council England and produced with support from Spike Island, Bristol. Please note this event is specifically for teachers and those working in schools and education settings; please get in touch with Tom, Learning Project Manager, if you have any questions - tsherriff@bowarts.com
Title: Teachers' Private View: Mark of Cane: Kat Anderson
Subtitle: A chance for teachers to relax at a drop-in artist workshop and a private view of our latest show, and an opportunity to learn about we do.

Refund_Policy: NA
Description: Join us as we share space with DeLovie Kwagala - a queer non-binary filmmaker, activist and photographer from Uganda. During the evening, we will be screening their short film THAT UGANDAN FLAMING HOMOSEXUAL and discussing their art and activism. ¬† Free event  Date ‚Äì Tuesday March 12th 2024¬†Time ‚Äì 6-8pm ¬†Location - @ Africa Centre¬† 66 Great Suffolk St, London SE1 0BL¬† About the film¬† Weaving together pieces of a childhood. revisiting memories. archiving a self that had to retransform and reshape many times. A grandmother‚Äôs dress becomes a symbol for the transformation of traditions to make room for future generations. What legacy would you want to leave behind if you ceased to exist? How would you want to be remembered? As such, Delovie Kwagala¬†creates images that are necessary for their own becoming. The short film THAT UGANDAN FLAMING HOMOSEXUAL tells the story of growing up queer in Uganda from a personal perspective.¬† ¬† About the filmmaker¬† DeLovie Kwagala (Papa De) is the first openly non binary queer photographer from Uganda, an international award winning multi anti disciplinary visual artist, human rights defender and the founder of Hashtagwhatnext, a movement and community led organisation aiming at empowering queer youth migrants through artivism with the focus of creating safe pathways to safety through international collaborations. They are currently working on an art residency in Berlin and working globally.¬† ¬† About Chakula programme ¬† The Chakula programme at the Africa Centre is a monthly series of events, workshops and dialogues geared towards supporting and empowering Black and African LGBTQ+ communities. ¬† The event space is wheelchair accessible. There will be photography and filming during the event.
Title: Chakula In Conversation with Delovie Kwagala aka Papa De
Subtitle: Join us for a screening of short film THAT UGANDAN FLAMING HOMOSEXUAL by DeLovie Kwagala followed Q&A and discussion

Description: The Faculty of Population Health Sciences has a requirement that PGR students all complete Active Bystander Training as part of their course.  This involves completing the online module and attending a live workshop. The workshops that we organised in February received excellent feedback from attendants, so we have organised a new session for those who were not able to attend.  The training will teach you what constitutes bullying, harassment and sexual misconduct, with a focus on experiences of PhD students. A crucial part of it is showing you how you can safely intervene if you witness these behaviours. You will also be informed of ways you can get support from UCL and the Students‚Äô Union and how to report any incidents you might witness.

Subtitle: We are looking forward to seeing you at the second Active Bystander Training of the year. This event is for students in the FPHS only.

Description: FAQ: Q: How does JobFairX work for job seekers? A: At JobFairX, we match job seekers like you with employers who have registered for the virtual job fair. When you sign up and create a profile, we collect information about your qualifications, skills, and preferences. Our advanced matching algorithm analyzes this data to identify suitable job opportunities. If your qualifications align with a job, you'll receive an email invitation to schedule an interview with the employer during the fair. Our streamlined process saves you time on your job search. Q: How do you match job seekers with employers? A: We match job seekers with employers based on the qualifications and preferences provided in your profile. Our advanced algorithm analyzes your skills, experience, location, and industry to identify suitable job opportunities. If your qualifications align with a job, we send you an email invitation to schedule an interview with the employer during the virtual job fair. The matching process is automated and tailored to your profile information. Q: How can I prepare for a virtual job fair with JobFairX? A: To make the most of your virtual job fair experience, we recommend the following preparation steps: Update your profile with accurate and up-to-date information, including your skills, experience, and job preferences. Ensure your resume is well-crafted and highlights your qualifications. Research general industry trends and interview techniques to be better prepared for potential questions. Test your computer or mobile device, internet connection, and video/audio capabilities to ensure a smooth virtual interview experience. Dress professionally and present yourself in a manner suitable for a job interview. Q: Is there a fee to participate in JobFairX virtual job fairs? A: No, participating in JobFairX virtual job fairs and scheduling interviews with employers is completely free of charge. You can register, create a profile, and engage with employers during the fair without any charges. However, please note that you can only attend the virtual job fair if you have a scheduled interview with an employer. Q: What should I do before the scheduled interview? A: Before the interview, make sure you have a stable internet connection and a quiet, well-lit environment. Test your microphone and webcam to ensure they are functioning properly. Familiarize yourself with the employer and their job requirements, and prepare answers to common interview questions. Dress professionally and have any necessary documents, such as your resume or portfolio, readily available. Q: Can I conduct the interview using a mobile device? A: Yes, you can conduct the interview using a mobile device such as a smartphone or tablet. However, we recommend using a desktop or laptop computer for the best experience. Ensure that your mobile device has a stable internet connection, and test the video and audio functionalities beforehand. Q: What happens if I need to reschedule my interview? A: If you need to reschedule your interview, simply log into your JobFairX account and navigate to your dashboard. On the dashboard, you will find the scheduled interview section, where you'll see the details of your interview. Alongside the interview details, you will find an option to reschedule. Click on the reschedule option, and you'll be able to choose alternative times. It's important to maintain open communication with the employer, so be sure to inform them of the situation and provide suitable alternative options. The JobFairX platform makes it easy for you to reschedule your interview and ensures a smooth process for both you and the employer. Q: When can I expect to hear back from the employer after the interview? A: The timeline for hearing back from the employer may vary. Some employers provide immediate feedback, while others may take a few days or weeks to make a decision. If the employer has mentioned a specific timeframe during the interview, be patient and wait until that time has elapsed. If you haven't heard back within the specified timeframe, you can follow up politely to inquire about the status of your application. Q: How do I participate in a JobFairX virtual job fair? A: To participate in a JobFairX virtual job fair, you need to register on our website and create a profile. Once you've registered, our system will match your qualifications with employers who have registered for the event. If your qualifications align with a job, you'll receive an email invitation to schedule an interview during the fair. Please note that you can only attend the virtual job fair if you have a scheduled interview with an employer. Q: What are the timings for JobFairX virtual job fairs? A: JobFairX virtual job fairs run from 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM. However, please note that you can only attend the job fair if you have a scheduled interview with an employer. The specific time for your interview will be communicated to you through the email invitation. We recommend being available and ready for your scheduled interview within the designated time frame. Q: Can I attend a JobFairX virtual job fair from anywhere? A: Yes, JobFairX virtual job fairs are accessible from anywhere with an internet connection. Our platform allows job seekers to connect with employers regardless of geographical location, making it convenient for individuals seeking job opportunities across different regions. Q: How do I access my scheduled interview on the JobFairX platform? A: To access your scheduled interview, simply log into your JobFairX account and navigate to your dashboard. From there, you will find a section dedicated to your scheduled interview. You'll be able to view the details of your interview, including the date and time. Please note that the JobFairX platform is designed to make the interview process seamless and convenient for you. Q: How does the interview process work on the JobFairX platform? A: On the JobFairX platform, the interview process involves a video interview conducted through the platform's video call feature. To ensure a smooth experience, we recommend logging into your JobFairX account approximately 5 minutes before your scheduled interview. The specific format and duration of the interview may vary based on the employer's preferences, but it typically involves a series of questions or a conversation to assess your skills and qualifications and will last no more than 15 to 20 minutes. It's important to have a stable internet connection, and we suggest testing your microphone and camera beforehand. Remember to present yourself professionally and express your enthusiasm for the position. After the interview, don't forget to thank the interviewer and reiterate your interest in the role. By following these steps, you can have a successful video interview experience on the JobFairX platform. Q: What if I face technical difficulties during the interview? A: If you encounter technical difficulties during the interview, such as audio or video issues, try the following troubleshooting steps: Check your internet connection and ensure it is stable. Refresh your browser or restart the JobFairX platform. Verify that your microphone and camera are correctly set up and enabled. Try using a different browser or device if the problem persists. If the issues persist, reach out to the JobFairX technical support team for immediate assistance. Q: How should I follow up after the interview? A: After the interview, it's a good practice to send a thank-you email or message to the interviewer within 24 hours. Express your appreciation for the opportunity to interview and reiterate your interest in the position. Use this opportunity to address any additional points or provide any materials requested during the interview.
Title: London Job Fair - London Career Fair
Subtitle: Connect and Interview with Top Employers

Description: The course will support employers in developing inclusive and thoughtful work environments, celebrating and encouraging diversity and helping migrant employees flourish at work and increase productivity. This course is aimed at team leaders, supervisors ,managers and anyone interested in diversity and inclusion. It will explore the benefits of a diverse workforce. The content will help support a migrant workforce and dispel some of the common misperceptions and biases. The presentation has been developed by a team of professional consultants from the social enterprise TogetherintheUK and is based on their long term experience in working with, and for, migrants living and working in the UK. The content covers: ¬∑ Recognising the challenges of migration ¬∑ Ways of understanding our different cultures ¬∑ Inclusive communication at work ¬∑ Inclusive leadership To find out more about us, go to: www.togetherintheuk.co.uk To find out more, please email tgiuk@togetherintheuk.co.uk. The course is free of charge. The course will be facilitated by: Sin√©ad Mangan-Mc Hale: an experienced international Communications and Marketing Consultant with lived experience of migration. She has interviewed and written stories of migration for TogetherintheUK for the last three years. And Teresa Norman the founder of TogetherintheUK and an experienced Diversity Consultant, first leading EDI at the Department for Transport and working as a consultant with many different organisations since 2015.
Title: Join us on  March 12th for a free course on ‚ÄúManaging a Migrant Workforce‚Äù
Subtitle: Learn how to effectively manage a diverse migrant workforce in this free course on March 12th, 2024 ‚Äì don't miss out!

Description: BIRKENSTOCK STUDIO: WALK WITH ME is a creative pop up, which will be the workspace of a series of London-based artists-in-residence, each grounded by the values upon which BIRKENSTOCK is built. You are invited to join these featured artists in a series of inclusive and accessible creative workshops. To kick off the initiative in February, sustainable footwear designer Helen Kirkum will be joining us at Birkenstock Studio in Shoreditch for an eight-week residency. Helen utilises recycled and ‚Äòdead stock‚Äô materials to create artisanal & authentic pieces - from sneakers to furniture and beyond. Her process celebrates the nuances of the handmade and makes us question the very meaning of art, design and consumption. The respective workshops will focus on DECONSTRUCTION and CONSTRUCTION and will be ticketed on a first come first serve basis. We will also provide all materials for the event. Come as you are. No equipment or materials are required. Availability is limited so register now for this unique opportunity. Workshop 2: RECONSTRUCT: CRAFTS & COMMUNITYIn the coming weeks, Helen Kirkum will be working with the community to repurpose BIRKENSTOCK materials into a bespoke piece of furniture that will be a part of the studio interior. During these upcoming workshops, you will upcycle unique personalised "tiles" of leather from scrap Birkenstock material using traditional hand stitch techniques, that Helen and her team will patchwork together into a lounge furniture piece. Join Helen Kirkum for an evening of creative reflection and handcraft, all the while chatting through creative goals and common struggles for creatives in 2024 with Helen and the team. Connect with like-minded creatives using the meditative process of handcrafting to inspire new ideas and aspirations for 2024. Please note: Digital content will be captured during each workshop for use on BIRKENSTOCK and partner channels.
Title: Helen Kirkum presents - RECONSTRUCT: CRAFTS & COMMUNITY #4
Subtitle: Join us in learning how to work leather as you're helping to create a real piece of furniture.

Description: The Staffordshire Hoard is the largest ‚Äòtreasure‚Äô ever found from the early medieval period, discovered by a metal detectorist near Lichfield (north of Birmingham), in July 2009. It contains a unique combination of extraordinary objects ‚Äï mostly of the warrior elite but also with stunning items of the emerging church. Made mainly between c. 570 and c. 650 AD, almost all are in gold or silver, many with inlaid garnets, and they display exquisite craftwork and artistry. They include fittings dismantled from swords, saddles, reliquaries, a cross-standard and a kingly helmet. This talk will review the collection and consider how it has transformed our understanding of the period. This Seminar will take place in room 612 at the Institute of Archaeology. In person attendance only.
Title: Medieval Seminar Series: Chris Fern
Subtitle: Reflections on the Staffordshire Hoard, an unparalleled collection of glittering war-gear from 7th century AD Britain [IoA Room 612]

Description: Please note: This Eventbrite page is for the March 12, 2024 event taking place in the Culture Lab at UCL East. You are invited to join students from UCL‚Äôs Public History MA programme and UCL Special Collections, in conjunction with the Eugenics Legacy Education Project (ELEP), for an interactive workshop about the women scientists who worked on eugenics research in the early twentieth century at UCL‚Äôs Galton Laboratory for National Eugenics. Using Galton Laboratory publications from UCL Special Collections, we will critically engage with the lab‚Äôs research output and what its legacy means for us as UCL students and staff today. The same workshop will be run twice, once at UCL East and once at Bloomsbury. Please register through Eventbrite.Feel free to share this invitation with other UCL staff, students, and other interested parties. UCL EAST When: Tuesday 12 March, 12.30-1.30 pm Where: Culture Lab, Marshgate Building, UCL East, London E20 2AF (Travel directions) There will be an additional 30 minutes available after each workshop for those who wish to continue the conversation about this topic and to examine the archival materials in more detail. Photographs will be taken during these events. Please let us know when you arrive if you do not wish to be photographed. For any inquiries, please email madeline.chase.23@ucl.ac.uk.
Title: The Women Scientists of UCL's Galton Laboratory for National Eugenics
Subtitle: An interactive workshop about the women scientists who worked on eugenics research in the early twentieth century at UCL‚Äôs Galton Laboratory

A Death Caf√© is an open, accessible and confidential space for those interested in talking about anything in relation to death. For further information visit the Death Caf√© Website at https://deathcafe.com/ TÔªøhe Electric Elephant is a community cafe generously hosting our event. Description: ELP is delighted to welcome Anne Desmet RA for our next Artist‚Äôs Talk. The focus of Desmet‚Äôs work shifts between Italy (where she was a Rome Scholar in Printmaking, 1989/90) and London. Her subject matter pulls in two directions: one body of work is essentially topographical, but subject to metamorphoses and mutations; the other is concerned with intuitive architectural fantasies, urban myths and histories of urban destruction and regeneration: such as the Tower of Babel and Italy's Mt. Vesuvius. She aims to suggest the sense of timelessness and solidity that architectural forms can convey, as well as their impermanence and vulnerability. Her works also look at the transformative effects of weather on the built environment. Her latest works are exploring the theme of ‚Äúkaleidoscope‚Äù and the way in which re-envisioning a subject through a pattern-generating kaleidoscopic lens can alter and expand one‚Äôs perceptions of the subject viewed. Anne will be presenting at the East London Printmakers‚Äô studio.
Title: ELP Talks Print with Anne Desmet RA
Subtitle: Join East London Printmakers for an evening talk with Anne Desmet RA.

Description: Bity Booker is an Italian/Australian folk singer-songwriter and visual artist who lives in London. She is a lover of nature, animals and folklore. Her work is inspired by the weird and wonderful quirky stories in our world and her deep and curious imagination. Bity grew up in an artistic family in the countryside in Umbria, she graduated from Art School in Italy and lived between Italy, Australia and England. She had an eclectic musical journey, in her teens she became involved in the heavy metal underground scene and sang in metal bands, alongside writing her own original material with classical guitar and voice. She also sang in choirs in Italy and Australia while studying ethnomusicology and anthropology. Musically, she is inspired by the distinctive voices of John Jacob Niles, Malvina Reynolds, Vashti Bunyan, The Incredible String Band, Connie Converse, Buffy Sainte-Marie, Molly Drake but also traditional folk music and singers, opera and psychedelia. Bity has developed her own musical and visual world, she has a distinctive and bewitching voice, her songs are melodically addictive, rich of storytelling which captivates and draws in her audience for more. She releases music on her own DIY music label, FreakFolk Records, and has illustrated three original song books.*Bity is pronounced 'Beatie', short for Beatrice. Hannah Lou Larsen, formerly known as Asthmatic Harp, is a Scandinavian singer-songwriter currently based in Oxford, UK. Her playful take on alt-folk draws comparisons to artists such as Regina Spektor and Laura Marling. Hannah Lou‚Äôs unique blend of autoharp, delay pedals, acoustic guitar, tape loops and found sounds invites listeners into a dreamy and reflective sound world. Originally hailing from Denmark, she began captivating London audiences with her debut EP in 2015. In 2018, she was handpicked for the prestigious Roundhouse Resident Artist Program. Hannah Lou's music has graced the airwaves of Danish National Radio and received accolades from Tom Robinson on BBC 6, earning spins from Hannah Peel on BBC 3. Her musical journey has taken her across the UK, Europe, and America, including a memorable performance at the 2022 Kite Festival. She has also supported Sam Palladio at the Camden Roundhouse and Mary Lattimore in Oxford during her recent European tour. With her latest single, "Buddha on a Shelf," she continues to captivate audiences with her introspective alt-folk sound, capturing the essence of her Scandinavian roots.
Title: Bity Booker + Hannah Lou Larsen
Subtitle: Join us for a amazing night of music and entertainment with the incredible Bity Booker and the talented Hannah Lou Larsen on March 12

Description: As part of the works for the new HS2 Old Oak Common Station, the existing Network Rail bridges are being extended to allow for the Great Western Mainline track alignment to be widened on the approach to the new station. The tracks will be rerouted to bring the Great Western Railway, Heathrow Express and Elizabeth line into the eight new overground platforms at HS2 Old Oak Common Station. The underpass walls of the bridges will extend approximately 100 metres and will encompass Old Oak Common Lane, a pedestrian path and a dedicated cycle lane. We are seeking the input of the local community on the final finishes of the underpass wall. These finishes specifically refer to the aesthetic design and appearance of the walls along the length of the underpass. As part of the design, we aim to draw inspiration from life on Wormwood Scrubs. Areas of Wormwood Scrubs are a Local Nature Reserve and recognised by Natural England as a site of natural significance due to its diverse array of plant and animal species. Our goal is to capture and showcase the distinct beauty of Wormwood Scrubs by gaining input from the community on how the nature, flora and fauna on the scrubs can be represented in the design finishes of the underpass. We will be holding this engagement events on 12 March to gather input on the design. We would like to hear your perspective and invite you to participate in interactive activities to help develop the finished design of the new Old Oak Common Lane Bridge underpass walls.
Title: HS2 and BBVS JV Drop-in: Old Oak Common Lane Bridge Design
Subtitle: Join this drop-in event to input on the design and appearance of the underpass wall finishes on the future Old Oak Common Lane Bridge

Description: A fun and free Tuesday Art Club at Stanley Picker Gallery for children ages 7-11. Parents are encouraged to drop their children off and return at the end of the session, to see what has been going on and visit the exhibition together. Sessions are led by a team of Kingston School of Art students and alumni, and complement the gallery‚Äôs programme, which this term is Larry Achiampongs' 'A Letter, A Pledge', showcaseing two films. Additionally, games and furniture fabricated in the workshops of Kingston School of Art, modelled on Oware games and an original Asante stool which the artist‚Äôs mother brought over from Ghana. Young artists will delve into the themes of the exhibition in fun and engaging ways ‚Äì combining interactive games, making, drawing, and discussion ‚Äì as they explore the practice and processes of contemporary artists, learn new techniques, and have the opportunity to contribute to a special participation showcase at the end of term! Clothing Occasionally, activities can be messy. We do our best with cover ups and water-based resources, but please ensure your child is dressed appropriately. Gallery location & Accessibility Stanley Picker Gallery is a full accessible venue, situated on a small island on the Hogsmill River, behind Kingston School of Art, an approx. 10-minute walk from Kingston Town Centre. We have free onsite parking. For directions visit www.stanleypickergallery.org/about/visit/ COVID-19 If your child is feeling unwell or has been in contact with someone with symptoms of Covid-19, please do not visit. Our commitment to our visitors: ‚Ä¢ We are limiting visitor numbers to aid social distancing. ‚Ä¢ We are leaving the windows in our building open for ventilation during certain periods. ‚Ä¢ We have installed sanitisation points at the entrance and around the building. ‚Ä¢ We have trained our staff to manage your visit in a safe and friendly manner. ‚Ä¢ Our onsite free car and bike parking allow you to travel independently to the Gallery.
Title: Tuesday Art Club
Subtitle: Join us for new creative activities inspired by artist Larry Achiampongs' exhibition, A Letter, A Pledge.
